content.subtitle: New type aliases language feature, improved Dart FFI

paragraphs.name: 77d4
paragraphs.text: Announcing Dart 2.13

paragraphs.name: 491c
paragraphs.text: New type aliases language feature, improved Dart FFI

metadata.alt: A graphic showing highlights of what’s in this post: type aliases, better FFI, null safety, Docker support

paragraphs.name: fc09
paragraphs.text: By Kevin Moore & Michael Thomsen

paragraphs.name: b8e0
paragraphs.text: Today we’re announcing Dart 2.13, featuring type aliases — currently our second most requested language feature. Dart 2.13 also includes improved Dart FFI and better performance, and we have new Docker Official Images for Dart. This post gives an update on the null safety feature introduced in 2.12, discusses the new 2.13 features, has some exciting news about Docker and Google Cloud support for Dart backends, and previews some changes that you can expect to see in future releases.

paragraphs.name: f637
paragraphs.text: Null safety update

paragraphs.name: 0c05
paragraphs.text: We launched sound null safety in March in the Dart 2.12 release. Null safety is Dart’s latest major productivity feature, intended to help you avoid null errors — a class of bugs that are often hard to spot. With that launch we encouraged package publishers to start migrating shared packages on pub.dev to null safety.

paragraphs.name: 0eda
paragraphs.text: We’ve been extremely pleased to see how quickly null safety has been adopted! Just a few months after launch, 93% of the top-500 most popular packages on pub.dev already support null safety. We’d like to extend our sincere thanks to all package developers for doing this work so quickly, and for helping the entire ecosystem to move forward!

paragraphs.name: 93b6
paragraphs.text: With so many packages supporting null safety, there’s a good chance that you can begin to migrate your apps to use null safety. The first step is to use dart pub outdated to check your app’s dependencies. For details, see the null safety migration guide. We’ve also changed our dart create and flutter create templates so that they now enable null safety by default in new apps and packages.

paragraphs.name: 2f21
paragraphs.text: Announcing type aliases

paragraphs.name: a40c
paragraphs.text: Type aliases is a new feature in the 2.13 language. It extends our earlier support, which allowed for creating type aliases of function types, but not any other types. This highly sought-after feature was the second highest rated in the language issue tracker.

paragraphs.name: 03fd
paragraphs.text: Using a type alias you can create a new name for any existing type, which can then be used anywhere the original type could be used. You aren’t really defining a new type, just introducing a short-hand alias. The alias even passes type equality tests:

paragraphs.name: 3ec4
paragraphs.text: typedef Integer = int;
So what can you use type aliases for? One common use is to give a shorter or more descriptive name to a type, making your code more readable and maintainable.

A good example is working with JSON (thanks to GitHub user Levi-Lesches for this example). Here we can define a new type alias Json, which describes a JSON document as a map from String keys to any value (using the dynamic type). Then we can use that Json type alias when defining our fromJson named constructor and json getter.

paragraphs.name: dda6
paragraphs.text: typedef Json = Map<String, dynamic>;

paragraphs.name: c22b
a7fd
c139
paragraphs.text: You can also call constructors on a type alias that names a class, so the following is perfectly legal:

paragraphs.name: 107a
49e7
paragraphs.text: By using type aliases to give names to complex types, you can make it easier for readers to understand the invariants of your code. For example, the following code defines a type alias to describe maps that contain keys of generic type X and values of type List<X>. By giving the type a name with a single type parameter, the regular structure of the map becomes more apparent to the reader of the code.

paragraphs.name: e090
be81
paragraphs.text: If you try to use types that don’t match, you’ll get an analysis error:

paragraphs.name: c7ff
paragraphs.text: m[42] = ['The', 'meaning', 'of', 'life'];

paragraphs.name: ac07
paragraphs.text: The element type 'String' can't be assigned to the list type 'int'.

paragraphs.name: 214a
paragraphs.text: You can even use type aliases when renaming classes in public libraries. Imagine you have an existing class PoorlyNamedClass in a public library that you want to rename to BetterNamedClass. If you simply rename the class, then your API customers will get sudden compilation errors. With type aliases you can go ahead and do the rename, but then define a new type alias for the old class name, and then add a @Deprecated annotation for the old name. Uses of PoorlyNamedClass will then cause a warning when used, but will continue to compile and work as before, giving users time to upgrade their code.

paragraphs.name: 37d7
paragraphs.text: Here’s how you might implement BetterNamedClass and deprecate PoorlyNamedClass (in a file named mylibrary.dart):

paragraphs.name: 7a13
paragraphs.text: class BetterNamedClass {...}

paragraphs.name: cd01
paragraphs.text:
@Deprecated('Use BetterNamedClass instead')
typedef PoorlyNamedClass = BetterNamedClass;

paragraphs.name: 9de7
paragraphs.text: And here’s what happens what someone tries to use PoorlyNamedClass:

paragraphs.name: fbc0
paragraphs.text: import 'mylibrary.dart';

paragraphs.name: 2ab1
faa9
paragraphs.text: 'PoorlyNamedClass' is deprecated and shouldn't be used. Use BetterNamedClass instead.

paragraphs.name: b958
paragraphs.text: The type alias feature is available starting with Dart 2.13. To enable it, set the lower Dart SDK constraint in your pubspec to at least 2.13:

paragraphs.name: 2f0f
paragraphs.text:
environment:
  sdk: ">=2.13.0 <3.0.0"

This feature is backward compatible, thanks to language versioning. Packages with lower SDK constraints under 2.13 can safely refer to type aliases defined in 2.13 packages, even though pre-2.13 packages can’t define their own type aliases.

paragraphs.name: 1fdc
paragraphs.text: Dart 2.13 FFI changes

paragraphs.name: 11d3
paragraphs.text: We also have a couple of new features in Dart FFI, our interop mechanism for calling C code.

paragraphs.name: 356f
paragraphs.text: First, FFI now supports structs that have inline arrays (#35763). Consider a C struct with an inline array like this:

paragraphs.name: 6b7b
f6ae
paragraphs.text: You can now wrap that in Dart directly, specifying the element type with a type argument to Array:

paragraphs.name: 2ef0

paragraphs.text: Second, FFI now supports packed structs (#38158). Normally structs are laid out in memory so that members fall in address boundaries that are easier to access for the CPU. With packed structs some of this padding is omitted to lower overall memory consumption, often in platform-specific ways. With the new @Packed(<alignment>) annotation, you can easily specify the padding. For example, the following code creates a struct that has 4-byte alignment when it’s in memory:

paragraphs.name: 955f
18dc
paragraphs.text: Dart 2.13 performance changes

paragraphs.name: fe45
paragraphs.text: We’re continuing to work on reducing the application size and memory footprint of Dart code. In large Flutter applications, internal structures representing metadata of an AOT-compiled Dart program might occupy a sizable chunk of memory. Most of this metadata is present to enable features like hot reload, interactive debugging, and formatting of human-readable stack traces — features that are never used in deployed applications. Over the previous year we’ve been restructuring the Dart native runtime to eliminate as much of this overhead as possible. Some of these improvements apply to all Flutter applications built in release mode, but some require you to forgo human-readable stack traces by splitting debug information out of AOT-compiled applications using the --split-debug-info flag.

paragraphs.name: fcaa
paragraphs.text: Dart 2.13 includes a number of changes that significantly reduce the space occupied by program metadata when --split-debug-info is used. Take as an example the Flutter Gallery app. On Android the release APK is 112.4 MB with debug information, and 106.7 MB without it (a 5% overall reduction). This APK contains a lot of assets. Looking just at the code metadata inside the APK, it was reduced from 5.7MB in Dart 2.12 and only 3.7MB in Dart 2.13 (a 35% reduction).

paragraphs.name: 43ce
paragraphs.text: If app size and memory footprint are important to you, consider omitting the debug information using the --split-debug-info flag. Note that when doing so you’ll need to use the symbolize command to make the stack traces human readable again.
Official Docker support and Dart on Google Cloud

paragraphs.name: d5a6
paragraphs.text: Dart is now available as Docker Official Images. While Dart has provided Docker images for years, these new Dart images are tested and validated by Docker to follow best practices. They also support ahead-of-time (AOT) compilation, which can dramatically reduce the size of built containers and can improve the speed of deployment in container environments — like Cloud Run.

paragraphs.name: f7ac
paragraphs.text: While Dart remains focused on enabling app frameworks like Flutter to drive beautiful pixels across every screen, we realize that behind most user experiences is at least one hosted service. By making it easy to build backend services with Dart, we support a full stack experience that lets developers extend their application to the cloud using the same language and business logic they use to power widgets on the frontend.

paragraphs.name: 04e0
paragraphs.text: In general, using Dart for Flutter app backends is an especially good fit for the simplicity and scalability of Google’s managed serverless platform, Cloud Run. This includes scale-to-zero, which means you don’t incur costs when your backend isn’t handling any requests. We work with the Google Cloud team to provide the Functions Framework for Dart, a collection of packages, tools, and examples that make it easy to write Dart functions to deploy instead of full servers for handling HTTP requests and CloudEvents.
Check out our Google Cloud docs to get started.

paragraphs.name: 621e
paragraphs.text: A few words about what’s next

paragraphs.name: 4cb2
paragraphs.text: We’re already working on some exciting changes for upcoming releases. As always, you can use the language funnel tracker to keep an eye on our progress.

One area we’re working on is a new set of canonical lints for both Dart and Flutter. Lints are a powerful way to configure Dart static analysis, but with hundreds of possible lints to toggle on or off, it can be hard to decide on what to choose. We’re currently working on defining two canonical sets of lints that we’ll apply by default in Dart and Flutter projects. We expect this to be enabled by default in the next stable release. If you’d like a preview, checkout the two packages lints and flutter_lints.

paragraphs.name: 7cb7
paragraphs.text: Finally, if you do deep embedding of the Dart VM runtime, please note that we’re planning to deprecate the existing mechanism for this. We’ll replace it with a faster, more flexible model based on Dart FFI (see tracking issue #45451).

paragraphs.name: c73f
paragraphs.text: Dart 2.13 is available now

paragraphs.name: fd35
paragraphs.text: Dart 2.13, with type aliases and improved FFI, is available today in the Dart 2.13 and Flutter 2.2 SDKs.

paragraphs.name: ee3d
paragraphs.text: If you’ve been waiting for your dependencies to migrate to null safety, you might want to check again, using dart pub outdated. With 93% of the top-500 most popular packages already migrated, there’s a good chance that you’re unblocked. We’d also like to extend a big thanks to developers who’ve already migrated!

paragraphs.name: d66b
paragraphs.text: We’d love to hear about your experience with the new features and changes discussed in this blog post. Leave a comment below or tweet us @dart_lang.
